div1.p: Carter states that the bibliographical work at the Library of Congress is about finished and describes the generous amount of time Brown has donated to the project.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, July 2, 1928
div1.opener:
Book (Misel)
Report weekly to Dr. Russell
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
July 2, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Thank you very much indeed for your most interesting letter of
June 25th. I greatly appreciate the data you gave me therein re things
West African and am looking forward to reading the paper you mention as
soon to be published in the American Journal of Tropical Medicine.

I know you will be glad to hear that Miss Brown and I are progressing
beyond what I had thought possible in so short a time. Last Saturday (a
half holiday at the Library of Congress) she came back to my apartment with
me and we worked until 10 P. M. going over one of our almost-completed files
and making Memoranda of the things yet to be done to it. They were very
few--and those mainly due to the fact that some of the books Father con-
sulted are not on the shelves and are being searched. We shall spend our
Fourth of July holiday going over the second almost-completed file--that
on West Africa. Remains yet to be done the strictly medical bibliography:
which will certainly in part have to be done at the Library of the Surgeon
General of the Army. Miss Brown started on itchecking the authors last Sunday afternoon as
we want to ascertain how many of the books, on purely medical subjects,
are available to us at the Library of Congress. This because I think that it will be
both quci quicker and less expensive to handle them where I now am--that is
if I have to get someone at the S. G's Library in Miss Brown's place. Miss
Brown has offered to take leave if necessary and go to the S. G's Library
with me and has also said that if it were necessary for me to engage someone
there more familiar with medical references than herself that she would then gladly
give her services free. This, I am sure, you would not wish her to do, but
it shows the spirit in which she is dhandling her part of the work.

Of course, what is left to be done on the two almost-completed files
[unclear] done! but I think that after the medical
medical

bibliography is cleared up, I can (at least temporarily) leave these unavoidable “loose-ends” [unclear]
[unclear]
and go over to work with Dr. Frost in Baltimore, which will really be
“the beginning of the end.” Also, if the medical bibliography goes any-
where near so well as the other has, I should be able to make the move
by the early part of August--possibly sooner: it will depend upon the
facilities available for long hard work, at a new place. These I shall
investigate as soon as Miss Brown has gotten a “line” on what books and
medical journals will have to be verified away from the Library of Congress. I am sure th
there is no more delightful place to work than the Library of the Surgeon
General of the Army, but whether one can remain after 4.30 (Government
closing time) etc. I have yet to discover,with the exception of Satur-
day afternoons in the summer: the Fourth of July and Christmas, one can
work at the Library of Congress until 10 P. M.--Sundays included.
div1.closer:
With very best remembrances, I remain
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
